clinical_study.brief_title: Circulating Tumor DNA to Monitor Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy in Breast Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Circulating Tumor DNA to Monitor Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy in Breast Cancer

lead_sponsor.agency: Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Hospital of Sun Yat-Sen University

clinical_study.source: Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Hospital of Sun Yat-Sen University

brief_summary.textblock: Investigators aim to investigate whether circulating tumor DNA is a sensitive marker to evaluate patients' response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy

detailed_description.textblock: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy(NAC) is traditionally for locally advanced disease, converting an inoperable to a resectable tumor.In recent years, it has become an option for patients of lower tumor stage to increase the possibility of breast conserving therapy. An effective method to monitor the response to NAC is important.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Follow-up time is estimated to be up to 5 years. The duration is from the date of diagnosis to date of death of breast cancer or date of death of any cause, whichever come first.
primary_outcome.description: The event is defined as death of breast cancer, which is a separate measure

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Follow-up time is estimated to be up to 5 years.The duration is from diagnosis to local recurrence or distant metastasis of breast cancer. Patients were followed up every six months in first three years, then followed up once a year.
secondary_outcome.description: The event is defined as breast cancer local recurrence or distant metastasis

biospec_descr.textblock: plasma separated within 2 hours, stored in -80 celsius refrigerator

study_pop.textblock: Breast cancer patient receiving NAC in Sunyat-sen memorial hospital

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female patients undergoing NAC
- Age: 18-70 yrs
- Any menopausal status
- Any hormal receptor status
Exclusion Criteria:
- Failed to retain blood sample before NAC
- Lost more than 2 blood samples during NAC
